title: Any indication where the patients clinical status/prognosis precludes intervention
High VE burden gt 10% on recent Holter
Exercise-induced VE burden
Sustained or paroxysmal AF or atrial flutter with new onset or change in clinical status
Sustained or paroxysmal SVT with previous ECHO and no change in clinical status
Ventricular arrhythmia
LBBB with no previous echocardiogram
RBBB with clinical suspicion of heart disease
RBBB without clinical suspicion of heart disease
comments: Primary care should refer to cardiology for review

title: Inherited channelopathy (e.g. Long QT)
Pre device implant
Infrequent supraventricular or ventricular ectopy with no clinical suspicion of heart disease
Sinus bradycardia
comments: Referral after discussion with specialist cardiology team. For discussion - consider not_indicated in all groups.

title: Tented T-waves in absence of history suggesting cardiac disease
LAFB in absence of history suggesting cardiac disease
Palpitations without proof of arrhythmia
Suspected heart failure and elevated NT-proBNP *
comments: "Refer to 1-stop HF clinic where available. Where not available, reasonable for primary care to refer direct for ECHO. Timing of referral as per NICE Guidance 2018"

title: Surveillance of known LV dysfunction to monitor effect of medical or device therapy
Surveillance of known LV dysfunction with change in clinical status
Family screening in subjects with 1st degree relative with inherited cardiac disease, inherited valvulopathy or inherited aortopathy.
Initial investigation in patient with suspected hypertensive heart disease
Baseline and serial re-evaluations in patients undergoing therapy with cardiotoxic agents
Reassessment  in patients on cancer therapies with significant (gt x2 ULN) rise in cardiac biomarkers [Troponin, NT-proBNP].
Hypotension in the absence of shock, clinical evidence of significant valvular disease or evidence of acute cardiac pathology such as AMI.
Routine surveillance in patients with HFPEF
Routine surveillance of maximally treated patients with HFREF in whom no further intervention is being contemplated and whose clinical status remains satisfactory
Routine re-evaluation in hypertension without symptoms or signs of hypertensive heart disease
Sinus arrhythmia
Syncope with previous ECHO and no clinical suspicion of heart disease and/or history of possible ICC
Syncope with clinical suspicion of cardiac disease
Syncope with family history suggestve of ICC
Probable neurocardiogenic syncope
Chest pain with no other symptoms and no signs of cardiac disease and normal ECG
Chest pain with abnormal ECG
comments: "ECG abnormalties do not include: sinus bradycardia, sinus arrhythmia or other changes not linked to coronary disease"

title: Exertional chest pain
Non-exertional, non-pleuritic chest pain.
Chest pain with FH of SCD or DCM
Chest pain with recent recreational drug use
Murmur with no clinical suspicion of cardiovascular disease and benign family history under the age of 50y and with no previous ECHO.
Murmur with clinical suspicion of cardiovascular disease

title: Pathological murmur
Chest wall deformities and scoliosis pre-operatively
Fatigue with no other signs and symptoms of cardiovascular disease, a normal ECG, and a benign family history.
History suggestive of endocarditis with other findings that would fulfill Duke's criteria with or without ECHO
Fever screen or CRP screen without findings to fulfil Duke's Criterial for Endocarditis with or without ECHO
Central cyanosis
Isolated peripheral cyanosis
Genotype positive screen for ICC
Desaturation on pulse oximetry with no signs of cardiac decompensation
comments: indicated if suspicion of platypnoea orthodeoxia

Chromosomal abnormality with undefined risk for cardiovascular disease
Cancer with suspicion of cardiac involvment on axial imaging
Muscular dystrophy
CKD IV or V with clinical suspicion of cardiovascular disease
Obstructive sleep apnoea
Diabetes with no clinical suspicion of cardiac disease
Dyslipidaemia with no clnical suspicion of cardiac disease
Suspected thromboembolic CVA, with no previous ECHO at, or after, event.
Peripheral arterial embolus with no obvious cause
Seizures, other neurologic disorders, or psychiatric disorders with no clnical suspicion of cardiac disese.
Storage diseases, mitochondrial and metabolic disorders.
Suspected PE, not confirmed.
Confirmed acute PE where thrombolysis or thrombectomy may be considered (severe hypoxaemia, haemodynamic instability)
Confirmed PE where thombecomy or thrombolysis will not be considered regardless of ECHO findings
Severe deceleration injury or chest trauma where cardiac injury is possible or suspected
Routine evaluation in the setting of mild chest trauma with no electrocardiographic changes or biomarker elevation
Initial evaluation when there is a reasonable suspicion of valvular or structural heart disease
